We are in this together. Be good to yourself and others.

Councilwoman Stephanie Gemski - Cumberland District 1
May 9 at 1:17 PM ¬∑

MAY IS BRAIN CANCER AWARENESS MONTH.

Brain tumors do not discriminate. They affect all ages, genders, and ethnicities.

HERE ARE SOME QUICK BRAIN TUMOR FACTS

An estimated 87,240 people will receive a primary brain tumor diagnosis in 2020.

An estimated 18,020 people will die from malignant brain tumors in 2020.

For the most common form of primary malignant brain tumors, Glioblastoma, the five-year relative survival rate is only 6.8%.

Brain cancer is not represented by a pretty color. You don't hear about it often, and very little research funding goes towards treatments or a cure. Its gray ribbon isn't sold on products or worn by athletes, but it affects the lives of many Americans every day in huge and devastating ways, including my own, and I would like to take this opportunity to spread awareness to the public. #findacure

Food Pantries are critically important community resources that meet Rhode Islanders where they're at. Currently, 53,000 people are served each month in Rhode Island at Food Banks and Pantries across the state.

I had the privilege of volunteering again today with my Community Outreach Coordinator at the Northern RI Food Pantry here in Cumberland. Each time I am there I am blown away by the compassion and powerfully good work this organization does. They serve our friends, our families, and our neighbors and they do it with grace. They represent so much of what is best in our community.

I've included the Northern RI Food Pantry website here if you're interested in learning more about what they do, as well as a clip my Community Outreach coordinator filmed last year while talking to some of the members of the team over there.
